betterquesting:10.desc:8:
I'm sorry, I failed you. For all I thought I was capable of, in the end I could barely protect this tiny fragment of the world. The fact that you live though, gives me hope my child. Though I am nothing but a whisper on the breeze now, I will assist you however I can.

First of all, this island, small though it may be, holds some key materials to begin to re-establish things. Take these trees for example - though you can fell them with your bare hands, their wood is innately powerful - such that even the crudest of wands carved from it may be of great use.

With a keen eye, you may have noticed that these trees grow small, hard berries that feel almost metallic to the touch. While they normally grow slowly, the wand you hold should be capable of encouraging the growth of these berries - simply use it on the leaves, and watch the §6Ironberries§f flow!

The trees aren't the only materials I was able to preserve with this island. Look around - water, rock and earth are part of all this too. That wand - it's attuned to the subtleties of this place, and can coax the earth and rocks here to aid you.
Using it on the stone will reward you with §6Clay§f, while the earth will indulge you with shards of life lost, and seeds to spread beyond this place.

I hope you weren't expecting to return things to how they were with a simple swish of a wand. With so much lost, there are limits to what can be done without a bit of good ol' fashioned physical labour.
Surely you're wondering what is to be done with those berries by now, but for that you'll need to make a wooden tub, and a terracotta drying basin.

Raw clay can only do so much, but if you combine it with some of the stone that forms the island's foundation, you should have a furnace vessel that can handle enough heat to actually cook things, including the clay itself.

At this point, perhaps you wish to move water around, or perhaps you find yourself handling some other liquid. Either way, I can show you how to use wood to create a rough bucket. It won't hold up to anything hot, but it'll do for a start I'm sure.

I warned you about the manual labour, right? Well here it comes. Stick some of those §6Ironberries§f in the §6Crushing Tub§f then get to jumping. As hardy as they are, these berries readily squish into a juice. Then, simply transfer the juice to a §6Drying Basin§f to start producing §6Tiny Piles of Iron Dust§f. Smelt these in a furnace, then combine and wa-la, §6Iron Ingot§f.
Now that you've got ahold of some iron, it's time to construct your next tool for weaving the arcane - a simple §6Cauldron§f.

Using the §6Cauldron§f is fairly straightforward, even for a novice. Simply fill it with a liquid, then add a reagent to transform either the liquid, the reagent, or both. Our goals however, simply require §6Liquid Mana§f - a coalescence of the magicks here. There should be enough residual magic in those §6Infused Pasture Seeds§f to transmute simple water into it for now.

§6Liquid Mana§f is powerful stuff. So much so, that you even find that sometimes the §6Cauldron§f hinders its effects. In these instances, you can just use any ol' hole in the ground and let it soak in energy from its surroundings to transform things that are exposed to it.
By now, you're probably a bit hungry, and those §6Ironberries§f don't do much for ones appetite, so let's use the Mana to get some better food going.
§6Leaves§f can be transformed into §6Wildberry Bushes§f this way, while you can also make §6Wheat Seeds§f from §6Ironberry Seeds§f in the §6Cauldron§f.

With the §6Crushing Tub§f, you can also crush §6Wildberries§f into juice. Combining this juice with §6Wheat Seeds§f in a §6Caulron§f, will then allow you to get seeds for the ever hot §7§6Chili§f plant. These seeds are unable to grow unsupported however, and will need to be planted on a §6Wooden Stake§f.

Moving forward, you'll need to be able to harvest harder materials than is possible with simple iron. If you can recall, §6Diamond§f was prized for its beauty before, but is also incredibly hardy. We can make good use of tools made from it, but first we'll need to collect it.
As the composition of §6Diamond§6§f and §6Charcoal§f are much the same, we can use large amounts of §6Charcoal§f with §6Liquid Mana§f to create small amounts of §6Diamond§f.

Having §6Chili Peppers§f is great for that spicy flavour, but it doesn't do much for helping any other part of the situation here. You can however, construct a §6Mill§f from stone to crush the Chili into a more reactive powder.

With §6Chili Powder§f at your disposal, you can start producing other, similarly hot materials. Combining the powder with §6Liquid Mana§f in a §6§fBoiling §6Cauldron§f transforms it into the dangerously hot §6Lava§f.

I think it's about time to turn up the heat, don't you? If I remember rightly, you can transmute §6Iron Nuggets§f into §6Flint§f in a §6Cauldron§f of §6Liquid Mana§f. This should allow you to put together a §6Flint and Steel§f, useful as always for starting fires, as may be required for further use of the §6Cauldron§f.

If you've got an excess of §6Chili Powder§f building up, and don't want to use it all on one §oreally§r spicy sandwich, throw it in a §6Fire§f. The residual magicks of this place will cause it to transform, imbuing it with a peculiar charge, making this new §6Redstone§f powder useful for anything remotely mechanical.

The latent magicks here have some strange effects, as you've already seen, yet none so peculiar as the conflict of §6Lava§f and §6Water§f. In an even fight, they'll produce an infinite supply of §6Cobblestone§f as they war, yet if §6Water§f gets the advantage and contacts the source of the §6Lava§f, it will turn it into hardened §6Obsidian§f§f.

With a handful of other seeds available to you now, maybe you wish to have the means for paper to write things down. Or maybe you've just got quite the sweet tooth. Either way, I think it likely you will find §6Sugar Cane§f a worthwhile resource to have at your disposal. Seeds for it can be obtained by adding §6Wheat Seeds§f to a §6Cauldron§f of §6Water§f.
With §6Diamond§f you can produce basic tools strong enough to harvest most things. The most important of these is the §6Pickaxe§f, as it will allow you to gather §6Obsidian§f.

Hmmm, I think you've become powerful enough now to have this world fragment partially tethered to your soul. Because of this, I can lessen my hold here, and divert some of my essence to helping you access other planes of existence. The first of these is the realm known as the §6Nether§f. Hopefully opening up this realm of fire will grant you the means to get many new resources. To access the nether, build a frame of 10 or more §6Obsidian§f (minimum size 4x5) and ignite it to open the gateway.

Upon visiting the Nether, you can start reaping the benefits of the resources held within, primarily §6Quartz§f, §6Gold§f and §6Amethyst§f. §6Quartz§f and §6Amethyst§f can be harvested from ores throughout this realm, while §6Gold§f is coveted by the §cZombie Pigmen§f which reside there. If you don't wish to tango with the pig folk, exposing small amounts of §6Quartz§f to §6Liquid Mana§f can transform it into §6Gold Nuggets§f too.

The Nether is itself constructed of a slew of materials you've not encountered before. I think it would be prudent to collect samples of some, mundane though they seem. Some, such as §6Soul Sand §fmay even have a reaction to §6Liquid Mana§f.

As an infant you watched me weave many a spell, yet I was unable to teach you the art before this catastrophe. But now I think it is finally time. Your skill in the arcane arts has developed enough that I think it should be possible to introduce raw mana into your body without too many adverse effects. To do this you will need a §6Syringe§f, and an §6Orb of Mana§f, both constructed of §6Glass§f. Combine these to crate a §6Mana Booster Lite§f, which you can use to directly inject the Mana into your body, enabling you to power spells.

The §6Amethyst§f you gathered from the §6Nether§f, it's similar in composition to the §6Sapphire§f I used to use in my experiments, but it seems almost chaotic in nature. I wonder if that could be tamed with some exposure to the essence of our world - §6Liquid Mana§f.

With §6Mana§f injected into your veins, you should be ready to start slinging spells around right?
...
Wrong! That §6Mana§f is limited, and if you aren't careful you can easily end up injuring yourself. It's much easier to avoid this mistake if you are actually aware of how much §6Mana§f is left in your body. This can be done with a §6Crude Halo§f - A poor, yet sufficient, imitation of those worn by the Angels.

The other piece of Garb critical in any spell slinging Wizard's wardrobe, is a §6Cape§f. A simple leather §6Cape§f made with some TLC will gradually absorb excess Mana spent while spellcasting, and help streamline the process - reducing the cost of spells.

Sapphire and Amethyst... These gems are much more in tune with magic than the diamonds we produced so far. Lets use some to build an §6§faltar§f. We should then be able to use this to channel various §6Rituals§f.

This Ritual Table is swirling with energy, both peaceful and malicious. You should be able to use this to restore some of the creature that were lost to void. Let's keep it simple to start with - Conjure some livestock, a §6Cow§f for example. You may require an approximation of its flesh to accomplish this, but I'm sure you can figure something out.

When I was younger, I made a deal with some very unusual creatures. These §6MeeCreeps§f, though they lack anything beyond rudimentary intelligence. Most of the time, they're completely incorporeal though, which makes getting things done tricky to say the least. In the past I had a box which I bound them to, tethering them to this plane. That was destroyed, but it should be possible for you to recreate it, and then you'll have your very own §mslaves§r err, prisoners with jobs.

"When are we going to actually start casting spells" you ask. Well, you can hardly cast spells that haven't been written yet can you? There's a few things we need to prepare, and then you can start writing whatever spells tickle your fancy.
Firstly, spellcrafting requires a big ol' altar. To build it, you're going to need a combination of quartz, wisdom wood and gold, along with an open 9x9 area.

§§§b§b§b§b§b§7§8§3§r§b[*Note*]This structure can be built from a schematic. press [DIVIDE] to choose a schematic to load, then use [MINUS] (numpad) to choose placement, and activate the printer to place blocks automatically.

I may have been a competent spellcaster, but I certainly never achieved true mastery, so my tutelage cannot be considered gospel. The old masters, sticklers though they were, had the foresight to write self-writing books on the fabric of the universe. So with the right materials, you can imbue books with their otherwise lost knowledge. For now, lets get you started with a §6Spellforger's Codex§f.

The spellcrafting altar can be fed mana by placing mana orbs on the §6Pearl Holders§f, but that's a rather small reserve, and requires frequent manual refilling. Building a Mana Battery structure will allow you to hold much more mana in reserve for creating your spells. Like the spellcrafting altar, the structure is built mostly of §6Quartz§f, §6Gold§f and §6Wisdom Wood§e§r, but also includes 8 buckets of §6Liquid Mana§f.

§b[*Note*]This structure can be built from a schematic. press [DIVIDE] to choose a schematic to load, then use [MINUS] (numpad) to choose placement, and activate the printer to place blocks automatically.

One of the ingredients you'll need for spellcrafting are the mysterious §6Nacre Pearls§f. It seems that exposing §6Glass Orbs§f to the unusual Nacre fluid causes it coalesce onto the orbs, forming pearls of differing quality. There seems to be a correlation with how long the orb is exposed to the liquid, but I never did discover exactly how long was best. Maybe one of the old masters did.

It seems you've gathered most of the things you'll need, so now is the time to begin actually crafting your own spells. To do this you'll first need to get a §6Magician's Worktable§f. With this you can combine effects to write your spells.

To do so you'll need to first choose a §6Spell Type§f or target from the top left, and drag it onto the paper. Do the same thing with a §6Spell Effect§f, and then you can drag with RMB to draw a line linking them. Order is important, so must draw from the §6Type§f to the §6Effect§f, not the reverse.
Provided you're carrying your §6Codex§f, you can then save the spell recipe to it, and see what ingredients will be necessary to craft the spell on the §6Crafting Plate§f.

Once you've gathered those ingredients, you can throw them onto the §6Plate§f §nin order§r with the §6Nacre Pearl§f being added last. With enough §6Mana§f available (either through continuing to add §6Mana Orbs§f to the §6Pearl Holders§f, or in reserve in a §6Mana Battery)§f you will see the spell be constructed, ending with a large burst of §6Mana§f, This returns the pearl, with the spell etched into it. To cast the spell, you will need to attach the pearl to a §6Wisdom Wood Staff§f.
§§§§I have few regrets, but burdening you with my final unfinished task is one of them. Yet not even death shall prevent me from assisting you in this endeavour.
Now that you've delved the depths of the Nether, it is nigh upon time I introduce you to some more complex magicks than the twigs and bowls you've used so far.
